bibl.title: Letter from Adrian Macia to Philip Showalter Hench, April 2, 1941

div1.p: Macia agrees with Hench that the original site of Camp Lazear is located on the Finca San Jose. He discusses the history of this area and explains physical changes on this property due to quarrying work.

div1.head: Letter from Adrian Macia to Philip Showalter Hench, April 2, 1941
div1.opener:
ADRIAN MACIA
INGENIERO CIVIL Y ARQUITECTO
HABANA
Havana, Cuba
April 2, 1941.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Hotel Nacional,
Havana.
Dear Sirs:
div1.p:
I was very happy yesterday to meet you together with Mr. Moran and I look
back with real pleasure to the trip the three of us made to inspect the site presumed
to be that of “Camp Lazear” and House No. 1, where the experiments in the research
work in connection with Yellow Fever and mosquitos as a carrying agent took place
in 1900, and in which experiments Mr. Moran took such heroic part. The site is
located within the section known as “Finca San José”, property of the firm of Rafecas
y Maciá S. en C. a partnership of which I am director.

I am very pleased to inform you that upon examination of the old pictures
you showed me of “Camp Lazear” and using them as a guide, I am absolutely convinced
that the wooden house that exists today at “Finca San José” is No. 1 of “Camp Lazear”
and is located today on the same site as that shown in the pictures.

Near this house there still exist the ruins of an old Lime Kiln and I was
able to place myself in what I am sure were the positions from which two of the
pictures you showed me were apparently taken. In each case the existing House No. 1
and the remains of the above mentioned old Lime Kiln wall appeared in the same relative
positions as in the picture. It is unfortunate that House No. 2 does not now exist,
having apparently been destroyed in 1926 cyclone, but there are remains showing
where it was located. These remains again support my conviction of the authenticity
of the site as, if we place an object upon this site and suppose it to be House No. 2,
we find it in the same relative position to House No. 1 and the old wall as that in
which it actually stood as shown on both pictures mentioned.

We bought this property in 1919 and the old house is leased to Mr.
Zunzunegui, whose father had rented said House No. 1 and lived in it from 1907 to
1936. Mr. Zunzunegui has been of great assistance in locating all this as he
perfectly remembers the family moving into there in 1907, when he was a boy of about
14 years, and living there until 1936. He still has that section under lease, where
he operates a quarry.

In addition to the foregoing, I can assure you, as an architect, that there
are two distinct characteristics in the old house today not found in that type of
building either of that period or later. One is a sliding window and the other the
shape and construction of the ceiling.

Referring to the point you brought up that, in the old pictures, the
ground appears to be flat while today it shows a distinct slope, I would suggest
that this is of no great importance as this could easily be accounted for by the
fact that quarrying work has gone on there for many years, great excavations having
been made near by and possibly something was done in part of the old “Camp Lazear”
site to provide drainage, all these changes possibly contributing to erosion of the
top soil, making it appear as a different looking lot of land.
Hoping that all of this might be of interest to you, I remain
